utterances: You know, I still have lingering feelings about it.
I mean, these, you know, these are people that I grew up with, so to speak.
And at the pinnacle of my career, you know, I can't say that it was anything other than just distasteful.
See, before Michael Battle came to Washington to run the Executive Office of U.S.
Attorneys, he was a U.S.
attorney himself.
He was the top prosecutor in Buffalo, New York during President Bush's first term.
He handled one of the biggest terrorism cases right after 9/11 - the Lackawanna Six.
So, the U.S.
attorneys that Battle was told to fire were, in many cases, his friends.
I didn't consider myself a former colleague, once a U.S.
attorney always a U.S.
attorney as far as I was concerned.
Battle says soon after he arrived at Justice in June of 2005, there were vague conversations about giving other people opportunities to serve as U.S.
attorneys, but nothing specific.
At some point, I was asked whether or not there were any U.S.
attorneys out there that maybe had some issues.
And quite honestly, I wasn't able to identify anyone that did.
He didn't hear anything more about it until Thanksgiving weekend, 2006.
Battle was coming back from visiting his family in Buffalo when he received a vague invitation to a meeting - 10 o'clock Monday morning, the attorney general's conference room.
MR. BATTLE: I couldn't find out what the meeting was about.
I reached out to my secretary.
But she didn't know either.

So Battle showed up to the meeting and all the big hitters were there: Alberto Gonzales, his deputy, Paul McNulty, legal council Monica Goodling, Chief of Staff Kyle Sampson - by the way, all those people have since resigned.
Kyle and I had gotten to be pretty good friends over the years, I think.
We'd played some basketball together.
And I, you know, I liked him and he liked me, and he sort of looked at me and his joking me and said, well, everybody here, I think, knows the purpose of the meeting except Battle.
And he kind of chuckled and I laughed, you know, thinking to myself, oh, this is not about me.
I'm not going to worry about it.
Then Kyle Sampson started passing around a documents.
It was a list of names, and Battle knew right away that this was a list of people who would be asked to resign.
By the time we left the room, it was very clear that I was going to be the one to make those calls.
The meeting was all about how the firing should work not whether these people should be fired at all.
Battle didn't expect to be consulted on the list, but Deputy Attorney General McNulty did.

I think Paul McNulty was a little bit surprised at, I think, Dan Bogden from Las Vegas was on the list and asked me after the meeting had I heard anything about, you know, Dan and I was doing, I said that I had not.
And we were both a little bit surprised.
In fact, Battle says he didn't know what any of the U.S.
attorneys had done that they deserved to be fired.
These were people that I know that had served, and at least, as far as I was concerned, with some level of distinction.
And so if they were being asked to leave, if it was for a bad reason that would surprise me, but maybe they had said that they want to move on.
I just didn't really know.
Over the months, evidence emerged that suggests some prosecutors were fired because they weren't partisan enough in their law enforcement decisions.
At the time, Battle had no reason to believe that anything nefarious was going on.
Battle says he didn't have any inside information about why the U.S.
attorneys were being dismissed.
He still doesn't.
He was just the messenger.
When I began to make the first call, I also developed a pretty bad headache.
And it lasted a whole day and the next day too.
Do you remember what you said to the U.S.
attorneys when you called them?
Singing helped to keep spirits up during weeks of strikes.
In the end, they won workers' rights unheard of in the Soviet bloc, and lasting moral authority.
Nine years later, Solidarity, the national union born at Gdansk, negotiated Poland's peaceful end to communism.
(Soundbite of boat-building)
Today, the shipyard looks, at first glance, half-abandoned.
Some workers have gone abroad, where pay is three times higher.
But the remaining 3,000 workers still cut, shape and assemble massive metal plates into enormous seagoing vessels.
For months now, Gdansk has been under pressure from the European Union to close two of its three boat-building slips.
The government and management say this would have led to bankruptcy and possible closure.
Worker Antoni Karwowski says that would've been a sorry end to a historic place.
(Through translator) The shipyard would die as a symbol, and that would be unfair.
The E.U.
said Polish government subsidies to Gdansk hurt other European shipbuilders, and was not used to restructure the yards as E.U.
law requires.
Poland's state secretary for economy, Pawel Poncyljusz, says Poland accepted structural cuts at the country's two other shipyards, but refused the E.U.
demands at Gdansk.
For Gdansk, close two of three slipways at once, in one year, this is unacceptable for us, because this is only one shipyard, which is with income at this moment.
And we can't close very fast these slipways and, I think, will be instead of this ship building activity.
So Poland put the Gdansk Shipyard on a fast track to privatization.
There was only one serious buyer, Donbass, a huge industrial conglomerate based in Ukraine.
Donbass recently bought into a major Polish steel plant.
Donbass' plans at Gdansk thrilled the shipyard's deputy chairman Andrzej Buczkowski.
Well, I would tell you this way, that they gave us such a wide offer just, in fact, to cover everything.
So, this is like, let's say, Santa Claus is coming, really.
They are solving all the matters for the shipyard, for the government, and against the commission also.
Donbass intends to diversify Gdansk, using shipbuilders to produce metal elements for bridges or windmills.
Head of the Donbass local subsidiary, Kostyantyn Lytvynov, says this is not about saving a symbol.
(Through translator) I wouldn't necessarily use the word savior because we are doing it from a business point of view.
It's a good business.
Would you call a person who buys bread the savior of a bakery?
The sale could end the pressure from Brussels to close two-thirds of the yard.
Donbass says it would rather pay back the state subsidies than accept Brussels' demands.
There's a lot of negotiating room.
The Polish government says that support was worth only about $13 million.
European Union officials say it may be at least three times that.
Many shipyard workers say they're delighted there's a buyer that's willing to invest in Poland's most famous shipyard, and it doesn't matter that it's a Ukrainian company.
But one legendary Gdansk figure is sorry to see the shipyard sold.
(Polish spoken).
I don't like it, says Lech Walesa, the man who led the historic strikes at Gdansk in the 1980s and later became Poland's president.
You don't sell your mother, he says.
The current president of the Solidarity Union Walesa helped found puts it differently.
He says the rich history of Gdansk merely demands that restructuring and privatization are done right.
Emily Harris, NPR News, Gdansk, Poland.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
And I'm Robert Siegel.
On Capitol Hill, the Senate is taking a page from the House of Representatives when it comes to debating Iraq.
Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid says he wants the Senate to break its procedural deadlock by taking up the House's streamlined Iraq bill.
We demand an up or down vote on the resolution that the House is debating as we speak.
The resolution says we support the troops and we oppose the escalation of the presence in Iraq.
Reid says the Senate will hold a vote this Saturday on whether to move forward.
Over in the House, things are moving forward ahead of a vote tomorrow.
The debate continued for a third straight day.
Each member has been given five minutes to speak on the floor.
This resolution does not help make progress in Iraq.
It does not provide a new approach in Iraq.
I'm not ashamed that I want my troops to come home.
I'm not ashamed to say that the babies that have died in Iraq that come from Cleveland's -
It is stunning to me that this body will consume over 36 hours of floor debate on a non-binding resolution.
The president's escalation plan offers an illusion, but only the real hope is that it offers a curic(ph) victory at best.
The voices of Democrat Bill Pascrell of New Jersey, Republican Bill Sali of Idaho, Democrat Stephanie Tubbs Jones of Ohio and Republican Geoff Davis of Kentucky.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Jacki Lyden.
The racehorse Barbaro injured in a heart-stopping moment during the Preakness last year has suffered another setback.
Barbaro had been recovering from a shattered leg and was doing well.
Now though, doctors have been forced to perform another surgery.
NPR's Allison Keyes has been following this story and she joins me now.
